questions.question: Why was IPv6 developed?

options.text: IPv6 was developed because IPv4 is running out of addresses and cannot support the growing Internet population and IoT.
To replace Ethernet switching with a new Layer 2 standard.
To make all Internet traffic encrypted by default.
To eliminate the need for routing by using MAC addresses only.

questions.explanation: IPv6 was developed because IPv4 is running out of addresses and cannot support the growing Internet population and IoT.

questions.question: What is the address size of IPv6?

options.text: IPv6 uses a 32-bit address space, like IPv4.
IPv6 uses a 128-bit address space, providing a vastly larger number of addresses than IPv4.
IPv6 uses a 64-bit address space.
IPv6 uses a 48-bit address space, like an Ethernet MAC.

questions.explanation: IPv6 uses a 128-bit address space, providing a vastly larger number of addresses than IPv4.

questions.question: Why must IPv4 and IPv6 coexist?

options.text: Because the transition to IPv6 will take several years and IPv4 networks still exist.
Because IPv6 cannot be deployed on LANs and is WAN-only.
Because IPv4 supports more addresses than IPv6.
Because routers cannot run IPv6 at the same time as IPv4.

questions.explanation: Because the transition to IPv6 will take several years and IPv4 networks still exist.

questions.question: What are the three IPv6 transition mechanisms?

options.text: Dual Stack Tunneling Translation (NAT64).
SLAAC, DHCPv6, and Duplicate Address Detection (DAD).
VLANs, trunking, and Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).
Subnetting, supernetting, and route summarization.

questions.explanation: Dual Stack Tunneling Translation (NAT64).

questions.question: What is dual stack?

options.text: It encapsulates IPv4 packets inside IPv6 packets across an IPv6-only network.
It translates IPv4-only devices into IPv6-only devices using NAT44.
It forces hosts to use only link-local addresses for all traffic.
Devices run both IPv4 and IPv6 protocol stacks simultaneously.

questions.explanation: Devices run both IPv4 and IPv6 protocol stacks simultaneously.

questions.question: What is IPv6 tunneling?

options.text: Transporting an IPv6 packet inside an IPv4 packet across an IPv4 network.
Transporting an IPv4 packet inside an IPv6 packet across an IPv6 network.
Assigning a /64 prefix using a stateful DHCPv6 server.
Converting multicast traffic into broadcast traffic on a LAN.

questions.explanation: Transporting an IPv6 packet inside an IPv4 packet across an IPv4 network.

questions.question: What is NAT64?

options.text: A translation method that allows IPv6-only devices to communicate with IPv4-only devices.
A method that tags IPv6 frames with VLAN IDs to cross a trunk link.
A process that replaces leading zeros with a double colon in addresses.
A technique that allows IPv4-only devices to communicate with each other using IPv6 headers.

questions.explanation: A translation method that allows IPv6-only devices to communicate with IPv4-only devices.

questions.question: What is the preferred long-term goal of IPv6 migration?

options.text: Keeping IPv4 permanently and using NAT everywhere.
Using tunneling for all traffic even when native IPv6 is possible.
Using only translation (NAT64) end-to-end in every network.
Native IPv6 communication from source to destination.

questions.explanation: Native IPv6 communication from source to destination.

questions.question: How are IPv6 addresses written?

options.text: In hexadecimal using eight groups of four hex digits separated by colons.
In decimal using four octets separated by dots (x.x.x.x).
In binary using 128 digits grouped in bytes.
In hexadecimal using six groups like a MAC address.

questions.explanation: In hexadecimal using eight groups of four hex digits separated by colons.

questions.question: What is a hextet in IPv6?

options.text: An 8-bit segment represented by two hexadecimal digits.
A 32-bit segment represented by eight hexadecimal digits.
A 48-bit segment represented by twelve hexadecimal digits.
A 16-bit segment represented by four hexadecimal digits.

questions.explanation: A 16-bit segment represented by four hexadecimal digits.

questions.question: What is Rule 1 for IPv6 address representation?

options.text: Omit trailing zeros in each hextet to shorten the address.
Replace any repeated digit with a single digit to compress the address.
Convert the hexadecimal address into dotted-decimal notation.
Omit leading zeros in each hextet.

questions.explanation: Omit leading zeros in each hextet.

questions.question: Why can trailing zeros not be omitted in IPv6?

options.text: Because it would make the address ambiguous.
Because IPv6 requires all hextets to be exactly four digits long.
Because routers drop packets with trailing zeros in the address.
Because trailing zeros indicate a multicast address.

questions.explanation: Because it would make the address ambiguous.

questions.question: What is Rule 2 for IPv6 address representation?

options.text: Use :: to replace one contiguous sequence of zero hextets.
Use :: to replace any non-contiguous zeros anywhere in the address.
Use :: to replace any hextet that contains the letter 'a'.
Use :: to replace exactly two hextets, no more and no less.

questions.explanation: Use :: to replace one contiguous sequence of zero hextets.

questions.question: How many times can :: be used in an IPv6 address?

options.text: It can be used any number of times as long as the address stays 128 bits.
It can be used twice, once for the network and once for the host portion.
It must be used at least once in every IPv6 address.
Only once.

questions.explanation: Only once.

questions.question: What are the three main types of IPv6 addresses?

options.text: Broadcast, unicast, and localcast.
Unicast, broadcast, and geocast.
Anycast, broadcast, and loopback.
Unicast Multicast Anycast.

questions.explanation: Unicast Multicast Anycast.

questions.question: Does IPv6 support broadcast addresses?

options.text: Yes, IPv6 uses broadcast just like IPv4.
No, IPv6 replaces broadcast with multicast.
Yes, but only for link-local communication.
Yes, broadcast is required for Router Advertisements.

questions.explanation: No, IPv6 replaces broadcast with multicast.

questions.question: What is an IPv6 unicast address?

options.text: An address used to reach all devices on the local link.
An address that uniquely identifies one interface.
An address used to reach all routers on the local link.
An address used to reach the nearest device in a group.

questions.explanation: An address that uniquely identifies one interface.

questions.question: What is an IPv6 multicast address?

options.text: An address that uniquely identifies one interface.
A special address that is routed only to the nearest device.
An address used to send to every device using broadcast.
An address used to send packets to multiple destinations.

questions.explanation: An address used to send packets to multiple destinations.

questions.question: What is an IPv6 anycast address?

options.text: A unicast address assigned to multiple devices where packets go to the nearest device.
A multicast address that sends packets to all devices in a group.
A broadcast address used to reach every node on a subnet.
A link-local address used only within the same switch.

questions.explanation: A unicast address assigned to multiple devices where packets go to the nearest device.

questions.question: How is an IPv6 prefix length written?

options.text: Using dotted-decimal masks like 255.255.255.0.
Using VLAN IDs like VLAN 10.
Using hexadecimal masks like ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff.
Using slash notation, such as /64.

questions.explanation: Using slash notation, such as /64.

questions.question: What is the recommended IPv6 prefix length for LANs?

options.text: /48, because it always matches ISP allocations.
/96, because it simplifies NAT64 translation.
/128, because hosts should not have network bits.

questions.question: Why is /64 recommended for IPv6 LANs?

options.text: Because SLAAC requires a 64-bit Interface ID and simplifies subnetting.
Because IPv6 requires a 32-bit Interface ID for every host.
Because /64 prevents the use of link-local addresses.
Because /64 is the only prefix that supports multicast.

questions.explanation: Because SLAAC requires a 64-bit Interface ID and simplifies subnetting.

questions.question: What unicast addresses does an IPv6 device usually have?

options.text: One global unicast and one broadcast address.
A multicast address and an anycast address only.
Only a single link-local address, never a global address.
Global Unicast Address (GUA) Link-Local Address (LLA).

questions.explanation: Global Unicast Address (GUA) Link-Local Address (LLA).

questions.question: What is a Global Unicast Address (GUA)?

options.text: A globally unique and internet-routable IPv6 address.
An address used only on the same local link and never routed.
An address reserved for all routers on a link.
An address that always starts with fe80.

questions.explanation: A globally unique and internet-routable IPv6 address.

questions.question: What prefix range is currently used for GUAs?

options.text: fe80::/10, because GUAs are link-local.
ff00::/8, because GUAs are multicast.
0000::/0, because any prefix is globally routable.
2000::/3 (addresses starting with 2 or 3).

questions.explanation: 2000::/3 (addresses starting with 2 or 3).

questions.question: What are the three parts of an IPv6 GUA?

options.text: Network ID, Host ID, and Broadcast ID.
MAC address, VLAN ID, and EtherType.
Global Routing Prefix Subnet ID Interface ID.
Prefix length, checksum, and TTL.

questions.explanation: Global Routing Prefix Subnet ID Interface ID.

questions.question: What is the role of the Subnet ID in IPv6?

options.text: It identifies subnets within an organization.
It identifies the vendor of the network interface card.
It indicates the multicast group the host belongs to.
It replaces the interface ID to uniquely identify a host.

questions.explanation: It identifies subnets within an organization.

questions.question: What is an IPv6 Link-Local Address (LLA)?

options.text: An address used for communication on the same link only.
An address that is always publicly reachable on the Internet.
An address used to send traffic to multiple destinations.
A special address used for broadcast messages.

questions.explanation: An address used for communication on the same link only.

questions.question: Can IPv6 LLAs be routed?

options.text: No, they are limited to a single link.
Yes, LLAs are globally routable by default.
Yes, but only within the same autonomous system.
Yes, if the prefix length is /64.

questions.explanation: No, they are limited to a single link.

questions.question: What prefix is used for IPv6 link-local addresses?
How are IPv6 GUAs statically configured on a router?

options.text: Using the command ipv6 address ipv6-address/prefix-length
ip address ipv4-address subnet-mask
ipv6 unicast-routing interface-id
ipv6 dhcp pool ipv6-address

questions.explanation: Using the command ipv6 address ipv6-address/prefix-length

questions.question: Why is the router LLA recommended as default gateway?

options.text: Because it is always reachable on the local link.
Because it is globally routable and reachable from any network.
Because it changes frequently to improve privacy.
Because it eliminates the need for Router Advertisements.

questions.explanation: Because it is always reachable on the local link.

questions.question: How can an IPv6 LLA be manually configured?

options.text: Using ipv6 address ipv6-link-local-address link-local
ipv6 address ipv6-address/prefix-length
ipv6 route ::/0 fe80::1

questions.explanation: Using ipv6 address ipv6-link-local-address link-local

questions.question: What protocol is used for dynamic IPv6 address configuration?

options.text: ARP
ICMPv4
FTP
ICMPv6

questions.explanation: ICMPv6

questions.question: What is a Router Solicitation (RS) message?

options.text: A message sent by a host to discover IPv6 routers.
A message sent by routers to announce routing tables to other routers.
A message sent by switches to elect a root bridge.
A message sent by hosts to request DNS name resolution.

questions.explanation: A message sent by a host to discover IPv6 routers.

questions.question: What is a Router Advertisement (RA) message?

options.text: A message sent by routers to tell hosts how to obtain IPv6 addresses.
A message sent by hosts to discover IPv6 routers.
A message sent by routers to translate IPv4 to IPv6.
A message sent by DHCPv4 servers to lease IPv4 addresses.

questions.explanation: A message sent by routers to tell hosts how to obtain IPv6 addresses.

questions.question: What information can RA messages provide?

options.text: Network prefix Prefix length Default gateway DNS information.
MAC address vendor code and Ethernet speed.
VLAN ID and trunk encapsulation type.
Hop count and routing metric.

questions.explanation: Network prefix Prefix length Default gateway DNS information.

questions.question: What are the three IPv6 dynamic configuration methods?

options.text: Dual stack, tunneling, and translation (NAT64).
EUI-64, DAD, and NAT66.
Static routing, OSPFv3, and RIPng.
SLAAC SLAAC with stateless DHCPv6 Stateful DHCPv6.

questions.explanation: SLAAC SLAAC with stateless DHCPv6 Stateful DHCPv6.

questions.question: What is SLAAC?

options.text: A method where routers assign IPv6 addresses using stateful DHCPv6 only.
A translation technology that allows IPv6-only to talk to IPv4-only.
A method where hosts manually configure a global routing prefix.
A method where hosts configure IPv6 addresses without DHCPv6.

questions.explanation: A method where hosts configure IPv6 addresses without DHCPv6.

questions.question: How does SLAAC generate the Interface ID?

options.text: Using only the subnet ID field provided by the ISP.
Using DHCPv4 options to build the address.
Using the default gateway address as the interface ID.
Using EUI-64 or a randomly generated 64-bit value.

questions.explanation: Using EUI-64 or a randomly generated 64-bit value.

questions.question: What is the EUI-64 process?

options.text: Inserts fffe into the MAC address and flips the 7th bit.
Removes fffe from the MAC address and flips the last bit.
Inserts 0000 into the MAC address and keeps all bits unchanged.
Converts the MAC address into decimal and appends it to the prefix.

questions.explanation: Inserts fffe into the MAC address and flips the 7th bit.

questions.question: Why do some OSes use random Interface IDs?

options.text: To reduce the IPv6 header size and speed up routing.
To improve privacy and security.
Because IPv6 forbids using MAC addresses in interface IDs.
To ensure all devices share the same interface ID for easier management.

questions.explanation: To improve privacy and security.

questions.question: What is Duplicate Address Detection (DAD)?

options.text: A process to ensure an IPv6 address is unique on the network.
A method used to compress IPv6 addresses with :: notation.
A process that assigns the subnet ID automatically from the ISP.
A technique to tunnel IPv6 packets inside IPv4 packets.

questions.explanation: A process to ensure an IPv6 address is unique on the network.

Using 2000::/3 plus the global routing prefix.
Using ff00::/8 plus the multicast group ID.
Using 0.0.0.0/0 plus a dotted-decimal host ID.

Stateful DHCPv6 allocation for every interface ID.
Manual configuration is required before any LLA exists.
Using the EUI-64 process.
